ratings.question_text: I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: What is the name of your TA?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This Lecture Series was one of the most informative, useful courses I have taken at FES. Having the benefit of experts sharing with us their own research made the topics cutting edge and informative.

If you are at FES working on marine or coastal issues I highly recommend this course for both of your years. The speakers are usually the best in the field and the workload is really low while you learn a lot.

As a lecture series, some of these questions do not apply - overall I enjoyed the series and the speakers. I would have liked more variety - not just scientists, but more artists, policy makers, lawyers, advocates, community members or workers impacted by the issue, etc. But, It was a nice overview of an issue that I did not know much about prior to the series.
Getting to hear from all different sides of the ocean acidification issue.
I gained a clear basic understanding of ocean acidification from all sides of the issue.

I love the fact that it's an entire semester on one marine topic. Really allows you to get in-depth exposure and given the opportunity to interact in the classroom and at dinner with leaders in the field. And because each week is a different discipline or approach to the same problem it allows you to see the merits of multidisciplinary work.
lectures on specific, targeted topics. perhaps future munson series should use input from the student body to pick a topic from a set list of say 3-4 options.

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: Perhaps, share the powerpoint slides with the class on classes v2.
There was a little bit of redundancy in the lectures towards the end, but this was understandable with different lecturers each week.
No improvements needed.
the time. i think the class would be better attended if it was during the day at lunchtime.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Instructors are great and really excited about the topics chosen each semester. Their excitement makes the class really good.
Not applicable.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: I am interested in coastal and marine issues.
I work in energy, on the law/policy side. It's always good to get fresh views on scientific issues impacted by energy consumption.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I am interested in ocean environmental issues.
It fits with my interest in coastal issues and a 1 credit course fit perfectly in my schedule.
My focus is on climate change and coastal/marine ecosystems so this semester's focus on ocean acidification was perfect.
experts from around the world come to give lectures on very specific topics. you learn more than in most 3 credit classes.
It was in addition to my regular course load - I just thought it looked interesting and would be enjoyable, and would give some insight into carbon issues.

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: and more.

No. I had hoped that it would be similar to Fall 2008's Munson's series. 2008's series were a lot more informative and engaging because it was on Arctic Ice melting, which has been studied for much longer and therefore more substantive.
Yes
Yes
yes
Yes - I enjoyed it and I learned from the course.

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: yes.
No. because much of ocean acidification is still new to scientists and managers, so the current knowledge is relatively sparse.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Focus on the issues/lecturers that interest you most, and take advantage of opportunities to go to dinner with them and continue the discussion.
Go every week and make sure to ask at least one question (even if very basic or boring). Makes the talks best for everyone.
Show up to the lectures - and attend the dinners, if possible. That was one of the most valuable parts.

Students already evaluated this course in hard copy form after the final lecture. Just don't feel like repeating myself. This was an excellent, timely topic for this year's Munson series and the lecturers were of very high quality.
